questiontext.text:
Exercise

Solve by decoupling the following first order system:

\(\dot x_1= {@eq_b[1,1]@} \qquad \dot x_2= {@eq_b[2,1]@} \qquad \dot x_3= {@eq_b[3,1]@} \qquad\) with \(x_1(0)={@init[1,1]@}, \qquad x_2(0)={@init[2,1]@}, \qquad x_3(0)={@init[3,1]@}.\)

\(\underline{x}=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text: We first translate the system of equations into a single matrix equation: \(\ddot{\underline{x}} ={@matB@}\underline{x}\). The eigenvalues are \({@evals_b[1][1]@},{@evals_b[1][2]@}\) and \({@evals_b[1][3]@}\), the eigenvectors are \({@evecs_b[2][1][1]@}^T,{@evecs_b[2][2][1]@}^T,{@evecs_b[2][3][1]@}^T\) and hence we substitute \(\underline{x}={@p_b@}\underline{y}\) to get \(\dot{\underline{y}}={@matD_b@}\underline{y}\). We solve the decoupled equations to get \(\underline{y}={@soly_2@}\), then write that in terms of \(\underline{x}\) as \(\underline{x}={@p_b@}{@soly_2@}={@sol2_gen@}\). To find the specific solution we solve \(\underline{x}(0)={@init@}\), which leads to the final solution \(\underline{x}={@sol2@}\).
